MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: palegreen">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a blue precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a green pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a yellow pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains blue in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the yellow pigment into a white pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: palegreen">green</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts white pigment into blue pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a green pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the blue color, so it will remain the white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a a second molecule with the same blue color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second blue colored molecule from gene 1 into a white pigment. The white color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>AABb</td> <td MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td></td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr><tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr></table></br>When either gene 1 or gene 2 is dominant, they express an enzyme that converts a precursor blue pigment into a white pigment. If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the blue pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: palegreen">green</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a green pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the green pigment, so it remains white in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: powderblue">sky blue</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tan">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a sky blue pigment from a blue precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: powderblue">sky blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a sky blue pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains blue in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the sky blue pigment into a white pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tan">tan</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts white pigment into blue pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a tan pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the blue color, so it will remain the white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> style='background-color: ivory;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a a second molecule with the same blue color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second blue colored molecule from gene 1 into a white pigment. The white color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: powderblue">sky blue</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: powderblue">sky blue</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a sky blue pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the blue pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tan">tan</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a tan pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the tan pigment, so it remains white in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tan">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: powderblue">sky blue</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a white precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a sky blue pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>recessive epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tan">tan</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a tan pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains white in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the tan pigment into a blue pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: powderblue">sky blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts blue pigment into white pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a sky blue pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the white color, so it will remain the blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a a second molecule with the same white color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second white colored molecule from gene 1 into a blue pigment. The blue color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes. If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the white pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: powderblue">sky blue</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a sky blue pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the sky blue pigment, so it remains blue in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: salmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a blue precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>digenic inheritance</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a yellow pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains blue in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the yellow pigment into a white pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td> <td MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: salmon">pink</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts white pigment into blue pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a pink pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the blue color, so it will remain the white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>dominant epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: salmon;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: salmon;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: salmon;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Correct
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a a second molecule with the same blue color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second blue colored molecule from gene 1 into a white pigment. The white color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the blue pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: salmon">pink</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a pink pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the pink pigment, so it remains white in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: salmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a white precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: salmon">pink</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a pink pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains white in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the pink pigment into a blue pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts blue pigment into white pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a yellow pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the white color, so it will remain the blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: salmon;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: salmon;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: salmon;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: salmon;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: gainsboro;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a a second molecule with the same white color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second white colored molecule from gene 1 into a blue pigment. The blue color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>recessive epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: salmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: salmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: gainsboro">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the white pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a yellow pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the yellow pigment, so it remains blue in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a yellow precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a brown color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the yellow pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes. MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the yellow pigment into a red pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains yellow in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the red pigment into a brown pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts brown pigment into yellow pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the yellow pigment into a tan pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the yellow color, so it will remain the brown color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the yellow color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Correct
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a yellow pigment into a a second molecule with the same yellow color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second yellow colored molecule from gene 1 into a brown pigment. The brown color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the yellow color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a red pigment from a yellow precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a brown color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the yellow color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td sienna;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a brown pigment into a tan pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the tan pigment, so it remains brown in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the brown pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lime">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: aquamarine">teal</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a green pigment from a white precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a teal pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lime">green</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a green pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains white in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the green pigment into a blue pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: aquamarine">teal</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts blue pigment into white pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a teal pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the white color, so it will remain the blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a a second molecule with the same white color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second white colored molecule from gene 1 into a blue pigment. The blue color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color:
