MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lime">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lime">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a green pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>recessive epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lime;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lime;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lime;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: aquamarine">teal</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a teal pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the teal pigment, so it remains blue in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>dominant epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: pink">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a white precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a tan pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains white in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the tan pigment into a red pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; tomato;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: pink;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: pink;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: pink;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: pink">pink</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts red pigment into white pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a pink pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the white color, so it will remain the red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a a second molecule with the same white color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second white colored molecule from gene 1 into a red pigment. The red color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: pink">pink</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a red pigment into a pink pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the pink pigment, so it remains red in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the red pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: aquamarine">teal</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lime">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a teal pigment from a blue precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a green pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: aquamarine">teal</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a teal pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains blue in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the teal pigment into a white pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lime;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lime;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lime;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lime">green</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts white pigment into blue pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the blue pigment into a green pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the blue color, so it will remain the white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>duplicate dominant epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: azure;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a a second molecule with the same blue color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second blue colored molecule from gene 1 into a white pigment. The white color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: aquamarine">teal</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: aquamarine">teal</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a teal pigment from a blue precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the blue color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: azure">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lime">green</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a green pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the green pigment, so it remains white in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: palegreen">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a green pigment from a white precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: palegreen">green</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a green pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains white in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the green pigment into a blue pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: palegreen;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: palegreen;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: palegreen;'>aaBB</td> <td cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: palegreen;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: palegreen;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts blue pigment into white pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a yellow pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the white color, so it will remain the blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>recessive epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: cornflowerblue;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: ivory;'>aaBB</td> <td MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a a second molecule with the same white color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second white colored molecule from gene 1 into a blue pigment. The blue color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: palegreen">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: palegreen">green</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: ivory">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a green pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a blue color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: cornflowerblue">blue</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a blue pigment into a yellow pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the yellow pigment, so it remains blue in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the blue pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a brown precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a red pigment from a brown precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a yellow color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the brown pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>dominant and recessive epistasis</th>  <th MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the brown pigment into a tan pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains brown in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the tan pigment into a yellow pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>AAbb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts yellow pigment into brown pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the brown pigment into a red pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the brown color, so it will remain the yellow color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the brown color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>digenic inheritance</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>Aabb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: sienna;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a brown pigment into a a second molecule with the same brown color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second brown colored molecule from gene 1 into a yellow pigment. The yellow color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the brown color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: yellow;'>AABb</td> <td MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: sienna">brown</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a brown precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a yellow color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the brown color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a yellow pigment into a red pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the red pigment, so it remains yellow in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the yellow pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: pink">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a red precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a red precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>dominant epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: pink">pink</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the red pigment into a pink pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains red in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the pink pigment into a white pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts white pigment into red pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the red pigment into a tan pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the red color, so it will remain the white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a red pigment into a a second molecule with the same red color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second red colored molecule from gene 1 into a white pigment. The white color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: pink">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: pink">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a red precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a tan pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the tan pigment, so it remains white in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lightsalmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: plum">purple</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a red precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a purple pigment from a red precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lightsalmon">pink</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the red pigment into a pink pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains red in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the pink pigment into a white pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: plum">purple</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts white pigment into red pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the red pigment into a purple pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the red color, so it will remain the white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a red pigment into a a second molecule with the same red color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second red colored molecule from gene 1 into a white pigment. The white color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lightsalmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lightsalmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a red precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the red pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: plum">purple</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a purple pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the purple pigment, so it remains white in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a red precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a red precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black;
