MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the red pigment into a yellow pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains red in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the yellow pigment into a white pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts white pigment into red pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the red pigment into a tan pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the red color, so it will remain the white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; snow;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a red pigment into a a second molecule with the same red color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second red colored molecule from gene 1 into a white pigment. The white color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a red precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a white color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the red color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td></td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td></tr><tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr></table></br>When either gene 1 or gene 2 is dominant, they express an enzyme that converts a precursor red pigment into a white pigment. If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the red pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate dominant epistasis and a <b>15:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a tan pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the tan pigment, so it remains white in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a white precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a yellow pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>duplicate recessive epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a tan pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains white in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the tan pigment into a red pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts red pigment into white pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a yellow pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the white color, so it will remain the red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> style='background-color: tomato;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>aaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>aaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>Aabb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: goldenrod;'>aaBb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: snow;'>aabb</td></tr></table>	Incorrect
MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a a second molecule with the same white color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second white colored molecule from gene 1 into a red pigment. The red color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show recessive epistasis and a <b>9:3:4 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>recessive epistasis</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>aB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>ab</td></tr><tr> <th align='center' rowspan='4' style='vertical-align: middle;'>Male<br/>&male;</th>  <td align='center' style='background-color: MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: goldenrod">tan</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a tan pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td></td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr><tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr></table></br>When either gene 1 or gene 2 is dominant, they express an enzyme that converts a precursor white pigment into a red pigment. If both gene 1 and gene 2 are homozygous recessive, then only the white pigment is present <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: yellow">yellow</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a red pigment into a yellow pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the yellow pigment, so it remains red in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the red pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate interaction epistasis and a <b>9:6:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: plum">purple</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lightsalmon">pink</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Gene 1 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a purple pigment from a white precursor. Gene 2 when dominant expresses an enzyme that creates a pink pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two pigments combine to form a red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes. MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: plum">purple</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a purple pigment. When gene 1 is homozygous recessive, it remains white in color. Gene 2 only has an effect on the pigment when gene 1 is dominant. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the purple pigment into a red pigment.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show duplicate recessive epistasis and a <b>9:7 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <tr> <th align='center' colspan='2' rowspan='2' style='background-color: lightgray'>digenic inheritance</th>  <th align='center' colspan='4'>Female &female;</th> </tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td><td rowspan="2"></td></tr><tr> <td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td>  <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lightsalmon">pink</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that inhibits another enzyme that converts red pigment into white pigment. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the white pigment into a pink pigment. When both genes are dominant, the dominant allele of gene 1 inhibits the production of the white color, so it will remain the red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant epistasis and a <b>12:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 1</td> <td></td> <td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table></br>A two step metabolic pathway determines the pigment color. When gene 1 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts a white pigment into a a second molecule with the same white color. When gene 2 is dominant, the gene expresses an enzyme that converts the second white colored molecule from gene 1 into a red pigment. The red color forms only when both genes are dominant, if either gene is homozygous recessive, the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><tr> <td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: plum">purple</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 1 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: plum">purple</td></tr></table><b>Only Gene 2 Dominant</b></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; vertical-align: bottom;" align="center"><table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td></td><td align="center">Genes 1&plus;2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: snow">white</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td></tr></table><b>Both Genes Dominant</b></td></tr></table></br>Both Gene 1 and Gene 2 when dominant express an enzyme that creates a purple pigment from a white precursor. When both genes are dominant, the two enzymes combine to form a red color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no pigment change and only the white color remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show dominant and recessive epistasis and a <b>13:3 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<table border="0" style="border: 0px solid white; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <tr><td rowspan="3"></td><td align="center">Gene 1</td></tr><tr><td align="center"><span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span>&darr;<span style="color: red;"><b>&#10005;</b></span></td></tr><tr><td align="center">Gene 2</td></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="background-color: tomato">red</td> <td align="center">&xrarr;</td> <td align="center" style="background-color: lightsalmon">pink</td></tr></table></br>When gene 2 is dominant and gene 1 is homozygous recessive, gene 2 expresses an enzyme that converts a red pigment into a pink pigment. Whenever gene 1 is dominant, then gene 1 expresses a protein that completely suppresses the activity of gene 2. When both genes are dominant, the inhibited gene 2 is unable to produce the pink pigment, so it remains red in color. If neither of the genes are dominant, then there is no active enzyme and only the red pigment remains.  <br/> <br/><p>The diagram and description above that explain the interaction of two genes.  <b>Determine the dihybird cross phenotypic ratio.</b></p>	<p>These two genes would show digenic inheritance and a <b>9:3:3:1 ratio</b>.</p> <table border=1 style="border: 1px solid black; border-collapse: collapse; "><colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="60"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> <colgroup width="80"></colgroup> lightgray'>AB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AABB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AABb</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBB</td> <td align='center' style='background-color: tomato;'>AaBb</td></tr><tr> <td align='center' style='background-color: lightgray'>Ab</td> <td align='center' style='background-color:
